VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
Maltreatment in Care
There were 1 substantiated incident of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period. During the special investigation 2023C0000037 staff was confirmed for
using physical punishment on a youth resulting in the youth substaning an injury on
the youth’s face. Staff also failed to follow the youth’s treatment plan and the facility
policy of no physical management of youth.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 2 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows:
The first CAP submitted was in regard to special investigation 2023C0000037
dated 1/20/23. The approved CAP involves the following. Retraining of all staff on
the no touch, violent situations, aggressive youth, behavioral management, verbal
de-escalation policies. The Chief Administrator is to be trained as a trainer in the
safety care training and then to train all staff. The facilty program statement is to be
updated to reflect the type of youth that will be admitted to the program. Along with
this program statement, the interview form will also be updated to ensure more
background information is learned about the youth so an appropriate assessment
can be made to determine the appropriateness of the youth for the program. Each
of these steps were reviewed during quarterly unannounced visits to the facilty
during this interim inspection. The facilty was found to have accomplished these
steps and conitnue to adhear the over-site review of these actions taken.
The second CAP submitted was in regard to special investigation 2023C0000107
dated 2/7/23. The violation involed staff engaging in physical management of a
youth when the facility has a no restraint policy the approved CAP involves the
following; retraining of all staff on the no touch, violent situations, aggressive youth,
behavioral management, verbal de-escalation policies. The Chief Administrator is
to be trained as a trainer in the safety care training and then to train all staff. The
facilty program statement is to be updated to reflect the type of youth that will be
admitted to the program. Along with this program statement, the interview form will
also be updated to ensure more background information is learned about the youth
so an appropriate assessment can be made to determine the appropriateness of
the youth for the program. Each of these steps were reviewed during quarterly
unannounced visits to the facilty and during this interim inspection. The facilty was
found to have accomplished these steps and conitnue to adhear the the over-site
review of these actions taken.

Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator(CA) identified the two special investigation 2023C0000037
and 2023C0000107 as occurring. She reported the steps taken which involve,
additional hours of training, role-playing, and case scenarios were added to the
training to help ensure staff fully understand the concepts and unscheduled
oversight visits from administration staff to ensure staff are following new training
and policies. New hires receive a 4-week training on the six core strategies. Weekly
“round up” meetings led by the case managers to ensure staff fully understand the
treatment being provided to each youth. Progress has been measured by the 100%
reduction in incidents at the facility. The development of an updated program
statement has helped the facility process new referrals to ensure the appropriate
youth are being placed at the facility. This has allowed the facility to gather more
background information about each referral. All staff have been trained on the
mandating reporter requirements and compliance is being checked by staff signing
they attended the training and understand the reporting process. The facility has
developed a role-modeling training scenario to help staff understand their
appropriate responses to violent situations. The round up meeting allow all staff to
understand the youth’s individual treatment plans to better responded in an
appropriate manner. They are measuring compliance by the reduction in afterhours
calls and the significant reduction in incident reports. The facility has updated their
hiring process to include more in-depth hiring questions which help the facility
understand the possible new hires response to stress and situations that could be
common on the facility. The CA has identified no barriers to compliance since they
have started the new actions steps of the two CAPs. The CA also identified there
were no unplanned discharges during this reporting period. However, this
assessment was written prior to the one unplanned discharge they had between
this assessment and the interim inspection. This unplanned discharge was the
result of a youth being arrested and placed in the local juvenile home. The youth
has since been replaced to a detention facility.
Staff and Youth Interviews
Interviews with staff were conducted and all staff report the new training and CAP
action steps are very positive and helpful. They believe these changes have helped
enhance their ability to provide appropriate care for the youth. Administrative staff
interviewed displayed a strong desire to provide the best practice for the youth in
the program and to support the staff providing the direct care.
Interviews with three of the four youth in the program were conducted. Although
limited verbal skills, two of the three youth were verbal and reported feeling safe at
the facility. The interactions observed between youth and staff were appropriate
and the staff were very attentive to the needs of the youth. The fourth youth was
attending an ABA therapy session during this time.
4

Description of Agency Walk Through
This is an older two-story structure north of downtown and in a residential area. The
structure is in fair to good condition and documentation indicates there is regular
maintenance being completed. Each room is furnished appropriately, and all
bedding is appropriately supplied. All plumbing is working appropriately, and the fire
extinguishers are up to date. There is ample food available which includes fresh
fruit and vegetables. The medication is locked as are the cleaning supplies. The
room check logs were present and the facility is documenting fire drills in
accordance with the rules.
VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules. It is recommended that the agency continue on their regular license.
